Hi John,

Thanks for elaborating...sounds like a fun and
interesting domain.

--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> I have almost 3000 pictures that I have taken with
> my digital camera.  I 
> don't want to enlarge all of them, but since I want
> to be able to enlarge 
> any one I want, it seems reasonable to build a
> 'general' mechanism that 
> works well for all the pictures, and hopefully for
> future ones as well.

What was your approach in gathering a sample of test
photos?  Were you trying to cover as broad a spectrum
of types of images as possible, or narrowly defining
the sample to similar images, under similar lighting
conditions?

I would think that the more diversity you have in the
training set, the more difficult it might be to
train/evolve networks for image enlargement.

I would think that networks trained/evolved to
specialize in enlarging particular types of images
(e.g., human faces) might be more efficient than a
generalist enlarger for any and all types of images.

What approach are you taking?

> Actually, it's an 8x8 input (64 nodes) and 8x8
> output, with an initial 
> configuration of only the center 2x2  input nodes
> connected via a single 
> connection with weight 1 to the output node that is
> in the corresponding 
> location in the enlarged image.

Okay...got it. :)

> Input node 'a' is connected with weight 1 to all
> output nodes 'a'.  Same for 
> b, c, and d.  This corresponds exactly to a 'nearest
> neighbor' or 'pixel 
> enlargement' algorithm.  The remaining input nodes
> are unconnected in the 
> hopes that NEAT will decide for itself which nodes
> it needs and which it 
> does not.  

That's an interesting approach.  It would be
interesting to allow inputs to evolve at any distance
across the entire image input, rather than a confined
grid.  There may be features in the lower right corner
that provide important information on how to enlarge
an area in the upper left corner.

While thinking about the domain you're interested in,
I'm also thinking about Go, and other game domains
that Philip, I, and others on the list are
particularly interested in.  We're interested in
experimenting with a similar approach...a mobile
viewing window which only looks at a portion of the
board at a time.  We thought it would be interesting
to allow the size and shape of the input window to
evolve as well.

And in Go, oftentimes there are features on one side
of the board that affect decisions on the other side
(e.g. ladders are sequences of moves along a path that
can either result in life or death for a chain of
stones depending on whether a friendly stone may lie
in the projected path of the ladder).

It may be that an optimal "window" is actually a
non-adjacent collection of inputs from various areas
of the board.

I'm wondering if this may be the case in domains like
image recognition and image enlargement.

> Okay, I have now read all of the archives for the
> lits, so I'm up to speed 
> on the 'roving eye' concept...  Yes, it is very
> similar, except it has no 
> control over the roving.  It is applied successively
> to every 8x8 chunk of 
> the image.

I wonder how it might perform if it were given control
over its movement.  If the window could rescan
particular regions and perhaps average its later
output values with its initial ones.  For example, if
the roving eye scans all the way to the lower right,
then decides to adjust some of the output values back
in the upper left, it can move back up and output new
values, which could either replace, or be averaged
with the old ones.  

Granted, this would be a hell of a lot more processing
though.

> The original image is 1984x1488 pixels.  The
> enlarged image will be 
> 7936x5952.  

Wow...those are big pics.  Might it be better to work
with smaller ones first?

>  But I felt that having 
> overlap would allow me to have a 'degree of
> confidence' in particular 
> pixels.  

This overlapping approach sounds like a good idea.

> My biggest problem at this point is time and disk
> space. :)  For now...

Well good luck with it, and keep us posted.  Did you
say which implementation of NEAT you plan on using?

Derek
